text.text:
### Prerequisites

We recommend that readers consult the sections **Understanding text** and **First steps** to gain a deeper understanding of the summarized information presented in this text

What is an Atlas?

This section of History Tracers brings together various maps. When we have this type of organized collection, we call it an atlas

History Tracers Atlas

This section is organized like a book. You can access a map directly by clicking its name or by using the navigation arrows.

The Atlas can be updated at any time based on new research.

Introduction

Before diving into maps, let’s explore how nature has shaped the structures that make map-making possible. To understand this, we’ll review the formation of stars and planets and examine the concept of force.

Can an atlas explore physics, biology, and history?

Yes! Fields of knowledge are interconnected, so we’ve included various disciplines to help you better understand how borders were shaped over time.

A Law

In his classes on Asian History, Dr. Abdul Karim Khan presents a fundamental relationship between History and Geography: "...if History has any laws, Geography is the first law". Based on this definition, studying the evolution of nature and our species from this perspective becomes essential

The Formation of Stars

Star formation in the universe didn’t happen instantly; it took millions of years for the first stars to emerge due to an initial lack of sufficient matter to form massive dust clouds, or nebulae. When these clouds eventually collapse, they form dense, hot cores capable of fusing hydrogen (H) atoms into helium (He) — the essential fuel of stars. Not all the mass within these clouds is used in star formation; some of it remains as material that can become planets, comets, or simply persists as dust

The Birth of Planets

Planets form within clouds of cosmic dust. At the beginning of this process, the collection of particles in the dust cloud is very sparse. As the cloud collapses, the dust grains come together and collide, forming larger bodies called planetesimals

These planetesimals continue to collide with other particles, creating an even larger structure known as a protoplanet. Gradually, protoplanets accumulate more matter and, over time, reach the stage of a fully formed planet

source.text: Leinhardt, Zoe M., and Derek C. Richardson.

text.text: Today, there is a general consensus on the process of planet formation. However, the definition of a planet has been updated: to be considered a planet, an object must be large enough to take on a spherical shape due to its own gravity, orbit a star, and be capable of clearing its orbit of other nearby objects

Understanding Gravity

In the previous text, we mentioned gravity when defining a planet, but we didn’t explain the concept in detail. This section expands on that idea.

The Space-time

For a long time, we understood space, where we move, and time, which records the sequence of events, as absolute and separate dimensions. As a result, we believed that time was the same for everyone, whether it was a person reading this text, someone traveling in a car, or even an astronaut on a journey to the Moon

This understanding began to change in <htdate0>, when Albert Einstein proposed that space and time are relative, depending on the observer's motion. Although this idea may seem strange at first, it is not noticeable in our daily lives because we move at relatively slow speeds. However, numerous experiments have confirmed the accuracy of this theory, allowing us to explain phenomena like Mercury's orbit

In <htdate0>, Einstein introduced a more comprehensive theory—the General Theory of Relativity—which resolved the issue of Mercury's orbit along with other cosmological mysteries. This theory presents two essential concepts for our study

• The universe can be described by a four-dimensional structure known as space-time, which combines the three spatial coordinates (height, width, and depth) with time, forming a continuous four-dimensional fabric.
  • In space-time, the presence of mass curves this structure; in other words, objects with mass distort space-time around them.

The planet and space-time

When a planet forms, it tends to acquire a spherical or near-spherical shape, like an ellipsoid. In doing so, it curves the space-time, as illustrated in this section’s figure. The effect of moving within this curved space-time is what we call gravity. John Wheeler famously explained it this way: "Matter tells space-time how to curve, and space-time tells matter how to move". A clear example of this phenomenon is our planet’s orbit around the Sun, caused by the curvature that the Sun’s mass creates in space-time

source.text: Hu, X., Shum, C.K. & Bevis, M.

text.text:
Is Gravity Really a Force?

We began by describing gravity based on our current understanding, but this has not always been the case. In the past, gravity was seen as a force, and using this perspective helps explain certain phenomena on Earth, as we will explore

Konstantino Adamopoulos et al. highlight that various systems in our bodies can be affected by the strength of the gravitational field. Additionally, they discuss how gravity has influenced species evolution, using as an example the arrangement of internal organs in aquatic snakes versus tree-climbing snakes

On the other hand, it’s also possible to consider that there is no "gravity force" per se, and that other forces might produce similar effects. For instance, the acceleration measured on the Earth’s surface is not constant and partly results from internal Earth pressure, leading us to observe an acceleration that could be associated with a force stemming from this internal pressure

source.text: Hu, X., Shum, C.K. & Bevis, M.

text.text:
Gravity as a Central Force

When we talk about gravity as a force in Newton’s model, we often simplify things, and these simplifications can sometimes lead to misunderstandings. For example, it’s common to hear that the "gravitational force" pulls objects "downward", which is imprecise and might cause some people to think of Earth as flat. The "gravitational force" is a central force that attracts objects toward Earth’s center

Finally, we’d like to use this gravitational model to address a question I’ve often received: "If the Earth isn’t flat, why don’t we fall off it in certain places?" According to Newton’s gravitational model, escaping Earth’s surface requires moving at a very high speed. Without reaching this speed, known as escape velocity, gravity keeps us grounded on Earth
We will discuss the concept of a flat Earth in more detail later.

Earth: A "Living" Planet

When discussing maps, it is essential to consider geological time, as continents have not always existed in their present form. Besides the continental landmasses, we must also account for tectonic plate movements, which play a major role in the formation and transformation of visible land structures

source.text: Andel, Tjeerd H. van and Murphy, J. Brendan

text.text: Before continents settled into their current configuration, Earth went through periods dominated by supercontinents. One example is Gondwana, a massive landmass that included what are now South America (Abya Yala), Africa, India, Australia, and Antarctica. This supercontinent encompassed the region from which our species would later emerge: Africa

source.text: Stampfli, G. M., et al, pp. 2 - 10

text.text: Over millions of years, Gondwana joined with other landmasses to form the supercontinent Pangea. Eventually, Pangea began to break apart due to tectonic plate movement, a process that, according to the most widely accepted geological models, led to the formation of the continents as we know them today

Continent: Antarctica

In this map, Antarctica is displayed at the southernmost part of the planet, with the regions of South America (Abya Yala), Africa, and Australia also visible

Continent: Africa

In this map, the Africa is higlighted, with the regions of South America (Abya Yala), Antarctida, Europe and Asia also visible

Continent: Asia

In this map, Asia is highlighted, with the regions of North America (Abya Yala), Africa, Europe, and Australia also represented

Subcontinent: South America (Abya Yala)

In this map, the South American (Abya Yala) subcontinent is highlighted, with Central America (Abya Yala), North America (Abya Yala), Africa, Europe, and Antarctica also represented

Subcontinent: North America

In this map, the subcontinent North America (Abya Yala) is highlighted, while the regions of South America (Abya Yala), Asia, and Europe are also represented. It is important to note that Central America (Abya Yala) and North America (Abya Yala) are presented as a unified subcontinent; however, some studies treat them separately

source.text: Bushnell, D. and Woodward, . Ralph Lee

text.text:
Continent: Europe

In this map, the European continent is highlighted, while the regions of the Americas (Abya Yala), Africa, and Asia are also represented
In this map, the continent of Oceania is highlighted, while the regions of North America (Abya Yala), Antarctica, and Asia are also represented

atlas.author: History Tracers Team
atlas.name: The History of a Theorem
text: The image in this section presents data that may raise questions for some people. In fact, a few have already asked me, "Why do I need to learn the Pythagorean Theorem?" To help illustrate the value of this knowledge, we will break down the image in stages and demonstrate the relationship between the theorem and geographic coordinates, which are used, among other things, in the GPS on your smartphone.

text.text:
The History of a Theorem

The Right Triangle

Let's begin with the first column of the image, specifically the sections labeled "(a) Pythagorean Theorem" and "(b) The Triangle and Its Components". In the center of image "(b)" we see the right triangle labeled "(a)". This triangle has two highlighted angles. The theta (θ) angle is formed between the adjacent side and the hypotenuse. Additionally, a right angle, represented by a square, lies between the adjacent and opposite sides, which are also known as the legs

How Was the Triangle Made?

To create this triangle, we used squares of equal size, which ultimately combine to form a larger square. First, we placed 16 squares along the base. On the side opposite the angle, we arranged 9 squares, aligning their corners with the far edge of the 4-square segment. Finally, by joining the points of the 1-square segment, we complete a total of 25 squares

Now that we understand how the right triangle "(a)" is formed, let’s explore the relationship between its sides. We see that the total number of squares along each side (9, 16 and 25) corresponds to the product of each side’s length squared. In other words, the total number of geometric squares on each side is calculated by multiplying the length by itself:

  • 9 = 3 x 3
  • 16 = 4 x 4
  • 25 = 5 x 5

Calculation 1: Triangle sides expressed as square areas.

We also observe that the sum of the squares of the adjacent and opposite sides is equal to the square of the hypotenuse:

  • 9 = 3 x 3
  • 16 = 4 x 4
  • 25 = 5 x 5

Calculation 2: The sum of the squares of the legs equals the square of the hypotenuse.

The Diagonal Triple

Following Dr. Daniel F. Mansfield’s research, we use the term "diagonal triple" to describe the relationship between numbers that satisfy this rule, as seen in ancient Babylonian texts that used positional sexagesimal notation. While there are similarities between the values on the Plimpton 322 tablet and those derived using trigonometry, we cannot conclude that the Babylonians used trigonometry in the same way as the Greeks or as we do today. Nonetheless, Babylonian knowledge of the right triangle is evidenced by the artifact known as Si. 427, on display at the Istanbul Archaeological Museum

The Pythagorean Theorem

Besides the Babylonians, there is evidence of the relationship between the sides of a right triangle in ancient Indian texts. However, the version of the theorem we know today originates from ancient Greece, over a thousand years after the Babylonian inscriptions. The Greek philosopher and mathematician Pythagoras is believed to have reached the same conclusion, either by drawing on the knowledge of other cultures or through his own studies. Thanks to him, we now have the formulation we recognize as the "Pythagorean Theorem" as shown in Formula 1

a2 + b2 = c 2

Formula 1: Pythagorean Theorem, where a is the adjacent leg, b is the opposite leg, and c is the hypotenuse.

The image in this section presents data that may raise questions for some people. In fact, a few have already asked me, "Why do I need to learn the Pythagorean Theorem?" To help illustrate the value of this knowledge, we will break down the image in stages and demonstrate the relationship between the theorem and geographic coordinates, which are used, among other things, in the GPS on your smartphone.

The Theorem and the Circle

Superposition of Figures

In figure "(c)", we place the right triangle from figure "(b)" inside a unit circle, meaning a circle with a radius of 1. Observing the superposition of these figures, we see that the radius of the circle becomes the hypotenuse of the triangle

Angles

In image "(d)", we isolate the triangle from image "(c)", where the triangle’s legs correspond to trigonometric functions. This triangle has two notable angles: the angle θ (theta), formed between the adjacent leg and the hypotenuse, and the right angle of π/2 radians (or 90 degrees), marked by the square on the opposite side of θ. This means the cosine (cos(θ)) and sine (sin(θ)) of θ are always separated by π/2 radians, or 90 degrees
Applying the Pythagorean theorem, as discussed in the section "The History of a Theorem", we arrive at the fundamental trigonometric identity shown in Formula 1

cos2(θ) + sin2(θ) = 1 2

Formula 1: Pythagorean Theorem Applied to Trigonometric Functions in a Unit Circle.

The image in this section presents data that may raise questions for some people. In fact, a few have already asked me, "Why do I need to learn the Pythagorean Theorem?" To help illustrate the value of this knowledge, we will break down the image in stages and demonstrate the relationship between the theorem and geographic coordinates, which are used, among other things, in the GPS on your smartphone.

Sine and Cosine

Trigonometric Functions

Trigonometric functions, such as sine and cosine, are typically defined using the unit circle, as illustrated in subimage "(c)" of Figure 1. These functions allow us to understand and calculate angles within trigonometry. In this section, we will focus on two specific functions: sine and cosine. The angle used in these functions is θ angle, measured counterclockwise from the x-axis

Sine

The sine function corresponds to the vertical coordinate of a point on the unit circle. In mathematics textbooks, this function is typically defined by Formula 1, shown in subimage "(e)" of Figure 1

sin (θ) = opposite sidehypotenuse

Formula 1: Definition of the sine function.

Cosine

The cosine function, on the other hand, represents the horizontal coordinate of a point on the unit circle. Its definition is given by Formula 2, illustrated in subimage "(f)" of Figure 1

sen (θ) = adjacent sidehypotenuse

Formula 2: Definition of the cossine function.

In Figure 2, we see the graph of the sine and cosine functions, which shows how these values change with the angle θ. Note that values on the vertical axis remain between -1 and 1, which correspond to the limits set by the radius of the unit circle

Figure 2: Graph of the Sine and Cosine functions. The source code for these representations and graphs is available on the project’s GitHub page (History Tracers Editors)

The image in this section presents data that may raise questions for some people. In fact, a few have already asked me, "Why do I need to learn the Pythagorean Theorem?" To help illustrate the value of this knowledge, we will break down the image in stages and demonstrate the relationship between the theorem and geographic coordinates, which are used, among other things, in the GPS on your smartphone.

Angles and Projections

A Jigsaw Puzzle Analogy

Before diving into angles and projections, let’s begin with a thought experiment to reinforce an important concept. Look at Figure 1, which consists of 8 subimages. Imagine cutting these subimages apart and turning them into a jigsaw puzzle with 8 pieces. Each piece represents a fraction of the main image, and if we give one piece to each of 8 people, each person holds 1/8 of the whole. When all the pieces are brought together, we reconstruct the original image. This exercise illustrates how individual parts, when reunited, recreate the original whole.

Understanding the Angle θ

In Figure 1, subimage "(g)" looks similar to subimage "(c)" but has a key difference: it displays angle values from two perspectives. The inner values represent angle projections on a circle, as if viewed from above. In contrast, the outer values represent coordinates on a Cartesian plane, shown around the circle.

?
Connecting Different Coordinate Spaces

In subimage "(g)", we see two types of coordinates: the inner values, defined by the radius r and the angle θ, are known as polar coordinates (Stover, Christopher and Weisstein, Eric W.), while the outer values correspond to Cartesian coordinates with the x and y (Stover, Christopher and Weisstein, Eric W.).

Do you know how to project polar coordinates onto Cartesian coordinates?

To explore this relationship, let’s use Figure 2 from the previous section, which shows the sine and cosine functions along with a table of specific values.

Figura 2: Gráfico de las funciones seno y coseno. El código fuente de las representaciones y gráficos está disponible en el GitHub del proyecto (History Tracers Editors)

Angle θ cos(θ) sin(θ) x y
0 1 0 1 0
π/2 0 1 0 1
π -1 0 -1 0
3π/2 0 -1 0 -1
2π 1 0 1 0

Table 1: Relationship between angular values and Cartesian coordinates for specific points.

Vertical Projection

In subimage "(c)" of Figure 1, we see how the triangle’s legs (catheti) relate to trigonometric functions. We’ll use this relationship to project values on the circle’s x and y axes. The definition of the sine function is given in Formula 1

sin (θ) = opposite sidehypotenuse

Formula 1: Definition of the sine function.

To simplify, let’s rename some components: we’ll use r, for the hypotenuse (the circle’s radius) and y for the opposite side, which we want to project..

Now that we have defined the corresponding names on the Cartesian axes and observed that multiplying any number by its inverse results in 1, we can conclude that the projection onto the y-axis is given by:

  • sin (θ) = yr
  • r sin (θ) = y r r
  • r sin (θ) = y

Formula 2: Projection of radius rr onto the y-axis.

Since sin (θ) ranges between -1 and 1, the full projection of r onto the y-axis occurs when θ is π/2 or 3π/2. For other angles, only a partial projection occurs.

Horizontal Projection

The horizontal projection follows a similar logic but uses the cosine function, as given in Formula 3

cos (θ) = adjacent sidehypotenuse

Formula 3: Definition of the cosine function.

Here, we again use r for the hypotenuse and designate x x, as the adjacent side. The desired projection is:

  • cos (θ) = xr
  • r cos (θ) = x r r
  • r cos (θ) = x

Formula 4: Projection of radius rr onto the x-axis.

As with the sine, the complete projection of x onto the x-axis only occurs at specific angles: 0 and π.

Projecting Space onto the Plane

In subimage "(h)", another angle θ, is introduced, which maps points in three-dimensional space. This angle spans from 0 (at the top of the z) to π (at the bottom). The section "Our Coordinates" will cover ϕ in more detail, but we note here that the calculations for ϕ are analogous to those in Formulas 2 and 4, now applied to angle ϕ.

atlas.name: Where are we on a circle?

text.text:
Where are we on a circle?

We know that, by definition, a planet is nearly spherical in shape. We also understand that our planet has continents, but we haven’t yet explored how to locate ourselves on it. In everyday life, we use addresses to find locations, but street names can change over time. Therefore, we need a precise and stable system of location

Imagine a segment of a sphere in the shape of a flat disc. This disc has a central point, which we’ll call O. From O, we can measure the distance to the edge of the disc, which we’ll refer to as the radius and denote by the letter r. Every straight line drawn from the center to the edge of the disc will have this same length, r.

To specify a particular point on the disc, we need additional information beyond the radius: the angle formed between two lines extending from the center. This angle, called theta (θ), ranges from 0 to 2π radians or from 0 to 360 degrees. Using the pair (r,θ), we can define the position of any point on the disc by moving from the center out to the edge. This is known as the polar coordinate system, where r represents the distance from the center, and theta (θ) ndicates the angular position relative to a starting line

source.text: Stover, Christopher and Weisstein, Eric W. Polar Coordinates

atlas.author: HTMW
atlas.name: Where are we on a sphere?

text.text:
Where are we on a sphere?

In the previous section, we extracted a flat disc from a sphere and learned to position ourselves on it. Now, let’s try a practical exercise:

Creating a Sphere

Draw a circle on a sheet of paper; you can use a plate as a guide, tracing around it with a pencil. Then, cut out the circle. Place it in front of you horizontally, and spin it a few times toward your feet.

By spinning the circle, we representing a sphere, similar to our planet, as shown in the image in this section. This exercise also highlights the need to define an additional variable to locate ourselves beyond a flat disc. This extra variable, represented by the Greek letter phi (ϕ), covers values between 0 and π radians, or 0 to 180 degrees. Introducing (ϕ) transitions us from polar coordinates to spherical coordinates

The origin

The figure in this section shows the intersection of the Equator parallel and the Greenwich Meridian, marked as point O. This serves as the reference point for all measurements of latitude and longitude.

Surface Coordinates

To determine our position on Earth's surface, we initially use the angular coordinates theta (θ) and phi (ϕ). However, in everyday terminology, these coordinates are known by different names: theta (θ) corresponds to longitude, and phi (ϕ) is referred to as colatitude. In geographic contexts, we also use a measure called latitude (δ), which indicates position relative to the Equator. The relationship between latitude and colatitude is defined by the formula: ϕ = 90º - δ. This is just one of the simplifications we will explore further

Longitude

In mathematics, longitude (θ) s expressed in values ranging from 0 to 2π radians or 0 to 360 degrees. When applied to geographic coordinates, the Earth is divided into two regions of 180 degrees each. The dividing line between these regions is the Greenwich Meridian line, established arbitrarily in as zero degrees at the Royal Observatory in Greenwich, England. Positions east of Greenwich are measured as X degrees East, and positions to the west as X degrees West

Latitude

Latitude (ϕ) is represented mathematically with values ranging from 0 to π/2 radians or from 0 to 180 degrees. In geographic terms, Earth is divided into two 90 degrees regions: the Northern Hemisphere and the Southern Hemisphere. In mathematics, however, positions south of the Equator are represented with negative values. Unlike longitude, which is measured from a prime meridian, latitude is measured from the Equator — an imaginary line dividing the planet into northern and southern halves. Positions north of the Equator are noted as "X degrees North", and those south as "X degrees South"

The Size of the Earth

The understanding that the Earth is spherical dates back thousands of years. The ancient Greeks reached this conclusion by observing how ship masts disappeared over the horizon and by noting the Earth’s shadow cast on the Moon during lunar eclipses. However, these observations did not provide a precise measurement of the Earth’s roundness. The first confirmed measurement was made around by Eratosthenes. On the summer solstice, he observed that in the city of Syene, the Sun’s rays reached straight to the bottom of a well, while in Alexandria, a pole cast a shadow pointing south. By knowing the properties of circles and the distance between Alexandria and Syene, Eratosthenes calculated the Earth’s circumference to be around 40,000 kilometers

The Earth's Diameter

More than 1,000 years later, Eratosthenes' calculations were confirmed under the authority of an Abbasid Caliph. A more precise measurement of the Earth’s meridians, and consequently of its radius, was carried out later by Al-Biruni. For his measurements, Al-Biruni was in Kath during a lunar eclipse, recording the event’s timing, while his colleague Abu’l-Wafa made observations in Baghdad. Additionally, Al-Biruni used the distances of caravan routes to determine the difference in longitude between Baghdad and Ghazni. With this data, he estimated the Earth’s radius to be approximately 6,371 kilometers, corresponding to an angle of 24 degrees at a latitude of 33 degrees north—a value that matches the Earth's average radius

Our Coordinates

Before pinpointing our location on Earth, let’s consider a question:

?
Reflection: Are we using the correct number of variables?

Could we be oversimplifying by using only longitude (θ) and latitude (δ) to locate ourselves on the Earth's surface?

Simplification

When we use only latitude and longitude to determine our location, we are indeed simplifying. This approach assumes a constant average Earth radius, estimated at 6,371 kilometers (Km) (or 6,371,000 meters (m))

To better understand this simplification, let’s look at an example. By assuming a constant Earth radius, we don’t remove it from our calculations; rather, we omit it in the final representation of coordinates. This allows us to express the locations of cities like Tokyo and Montevideo with latitude and longitude alone:

• Tokyo: (35,6764º Norte, 139,6500º Leste)
  • Montevideo (34,9055º Sul, 56,1851º Oeste)

All variables

To express coordinates more precisely, it’s essential to use the same unit of measurement for all coordinates. On the Earth's surface, when we work with angles, we can simplify calculations by omitting the Earth’s radius. However, for three-dimensional accuracy, we need to include the radius and convert angle measurements from degrees to radians before continuing with calculations.

• θ' = θ π180
  • ϕ = (90 - δ) π180

Next, we apply these converted angles in the formulas for spherical-to-Cartesian conversion, considering the radius r:
<center>(x, y, z) = (r cos(θ') sen(ϕ), r sen(θ') sen(ϕ) , r cos (ϕ))</center>

• Tokyo: (-3944126.27, 3350784.05, 3715609.67)
  • Montevideo: (2907683.28, 4341002.95, -3645642.93)

With this three-dimensional representation, we achieve a complete and highly precise location.

atlas.name: The Myth of a Flat Earth

text.text:
The Myth of a Flat Earth

What is a Plane?

To answer this question, we can simplify the definition given by Eric W. Weisstein: a plane is a rigid, two-dimensional surface

The mathematical definition of a plane alone excludes the possibility of a flat Earth. As we’ve discussed, continents and oceans are not rigid surfaces; they are made of matter, which is part of the observable universe and has mass. This mass requires Earth to have a third dimension, making it impossible for Earth to be a perfectly flat surface

We can further confirm this by observing a lunar eclipse. In these events, the Moon is not partially covered by a flat shadow; instead, a curved shadow is projected onto its surface—something the ancient Greeks had already observed

The Origin of the Flat Earth Myth

The myth of a flat Earth is, in fact, a relatively recent idea that emerged in the 19th century, rooted in false narratives. Among these was the incorrect claim that Christopher Columbus "proved" the Earth was round and that Greek knowledge of Earth’s shape had been lost. In reality, Columbus and his contemporaries were primarily concerned with the logistical challenges of a long voyage, such as the availability of supplies, as it was already well-known that Earth’s circumference was around 40,000 kilometers

According to historian Jeffrey Burton Russell, before <htdate0>, Columbus "discovery" of a round Earth was mentioned only superficially in some schoolbooks. However, by the <htdate1>, this narrative had become widely accepted in educational texts. The idea that Greek knowledge of Earth’s shape was entirely forgotten is also tied to a false narrative suggesting a supposed conflict between science and religion

Map Projections

The fact that Earth is not flat does not mean we cannot represent it on a plane.

To create a map projection, we first need a scaled globe model of Earth. Using this model, we select a technique to transfer the spherical representation onto a two-dimensional surface, such as paper. The image in this section demonstrates the "Developable Surface", technique, which is used with projections like the Conic Projection with a Standard Parallel. However, this is just one of many available techniques. In the work by the National Council of Educational Research and Training, Lambert’s projection and Mercator’s projection are also discussed; these are widely used for creating world maps

source.text: National Concil of Education Research and Training

text.text:
Human Migration

Our species emerged somewhere in Africa between 350,000 and 200,000 years ago, according to fossil evidence. However, the migration out of Africa did not happen immediately. Around 70,000 to 50,000 years ago, Homo sapiens began migrating to different regions of Asia. Fossils also indicate another major migration between 45,000 and 35,000 years ago, moving towards the European continent and northeastern Asia

Regarding the arrival to the Americas (Abya Yala), current evidence suggests that the first humans arrived sometime between 30,000 and 22,000 years ago, likely through multiple migratory waves. Recent studies on the Mapuche people, for example, indicate at least two major migrations toward the southern regions of the continent

The description of human origins and their dispersion over millennia was traditionally based on written narratives, which, in the most optimistic estimates, projected only 177 generations since the ‘origin’ of our species. With advances in knowledge and DNA analysis techniques, we have gained a clearer understanding of our migrations, and today we can more accurately estimate that the number of human generations is around 8,000

Cradle of Civilization

Observing the humanity distribution, constructions around the planet, the geography and the relationship between people, we observe the idea that an unique cradle of civilization is not consistent with our current knowledge. Although the origin of specie in Africa is widely accepted, the hipotesis of all civilization arises from Mesopotamia looks like improbable. With this context, we present in the map of this sectiion, this six cradle of civilizations teach in History Tracers
In the map in this section, we highlight the region where Sumerian cities flourished.

Sumerians

The Sumerians did not form a unified country. The various cities that arose across a large territory—from Mesopotamia to the Zagros Mountains in present-day Iran—were organized as independent city-states. These Sumerian city-states were eventually dominated by the Elamites, bringing an end to a period that lasted from approximately to

atlas.author: © Trustees of the British Museum (The British Museum).
atlas.name: The Ancient Babylonian World Map

text.text:
The Ancient Babylonian World Map

Our understanding of the world has evolved over time. In antiquity, people represented the "world" as their immediate surroundings, rather than as the planet Earth as we know it today. The image in this section shows the world as envisioned by the Babylonians. In the next section, we project this map onto a modern world map to facilitate comparison

?
Reflection: External Influences

As we began studying trigonometry, we noted measures like the famous "Pythagorean theorem" was already known by the Babylonians over a millennium before the Greeks. This fact raises the possibility that the Greeks either acquired this knowledge from other civilizations or independently arrived at the same conclusions more than a thousand years later (Mansfield, D. F.).

However, the exchange of knowledge is not limited to mathematics. Dr. Irving Finkel, in explaining the map featured in this section, also references a cuneiform text preserved in the British Museum. This text makes mention, among other things, of an Ark and its dimensions. Finkel points out a shared element between the map and this text: the word parsiktu, which denotes a unit of volume (Finkel, I, The British Museum ; Finkel, I, The Institute for the Study of Ancient Cultures, 50:06 - 56:11).

Additionally, Dr. Finkel notes that one of the mountains mentioned on the map is near a region called Urartu—located in present-day Armenia, Türkiye, and Iran—which corresponds to "Ararat" mentioned in the book of Genesis in the Hebrew text. Given the way the Pentateuch was composed, it is possible that Babylonian traditions influenced later Jewish narratives, as Dr. Finkel suggests (Finkel, I, The British Museum ; Finkel, I, The Institute for the Study of Ancient Cultures, 50:06 - 56:11 ; Torah, Neviim u-Khetuvim. Twenty-four books of the Holy Scriptures carefully translated according to the Massoretic text, on the basis of the English version, after the best Jewish authorities, Gênesis 8:4 ; Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia ; Davies, G. I.).

These archaeological discoveries demonstrate how stories and beliefs were exchanged among neighboring cultures and civilizations. Could it be possible, then, that these cultural influences extended even further, deeply shaping the traditions of distant peoples as they rewrote their own histories?

Rabbi Dr. Yitzchok Breitowitz, on the Jewish Learning Institute, reflects on the use of metaphor and allegory in sacred texts, noting how these elements may reflect historical events. Similarly, Dr. Abdul Karim Khan reminds us that concepts of creation and the world have emerged across different cultures, each with its own interpretations and symbolism

atlas.name: Comparing Worlds

text.text:
Comparing Worlds

To ilustrate the difference between Babilon vision of ancient world and in the past and our actual compreension, we followed Dr. Irving Finkel's analisis. We use the map of the section Maps of Ancient World: Babilonia, we rotate it and we put on top of our current understanding of world, as it is shwn in this section. It is possible to observe that Babilonian conception of the world did not include nearest regions, like India

Visigoths

The exact origin of the Goths is uncertain, as they left no early written records. Some scholars suggest they may have originated in what is now Poland. There is also debate on whether the Goths constituted a distinct ethnic group; some researchers believe they may have been a confederation of various tribes

The Visigoths, also known as the "Western Goths",  split from the Ostrogoths in the 4th century. One of the most significant events in their history is the invasion and sack of Rome in <htdate0>, led by their king Alaric I, who died shortly afterward. His successor, Ataulf, expanded Visigothic influence, conquering parts of Gaul and founding the Visigothic Kingdom there

After establishing a presence in Gaul, the Visigoths continued their expansion into the Iberian Peninsula around <htdate0>. By <htdate1>, they controlled the region shown in green on the map in this section

The Visigothic kingdom ultimately fell in <htdate0>. Although traditionally described as a Muslim "invasion", contemporary analysis suggests a more complex situation. The councils held in Visigothic territory reveal significant oppression toward women, Jews, and Arian Christians, leading parts of the population to welcome Muslim intervention

source.text: Ibn El-Kouthya, M. A. Cherbonneau, pp. 8 - 9,

text.text: At the height of their power, between <htdate0> and <htdate1>, the Banu Qasi controlled the area highlighted in green in the image in this section

Banu Qasi

The unification of Spain into a single political entity is relatively recent, taking place in . This unification contributed to Spain’s rich cultural and genetic diversity

Recently, some research and discussions in historical forums have suggested possible connections between the Banu Qasi and later monarchs in the Iberian Peninsula, or even with the prophet Muhammad. However, no primary sources have yet been identified to support these hypotheses
The image in this section shows the territory of the Kingdom of León before its unification with Castile in <htdate0>

The Kingdom of León

The unification of Spain into a single political entity is relatively recent, taking place in . This unification contributed to Spain’s rich cultural and genetic diversity
The Kingdom of León was an independent realm between and . Currently, History Tracers presents only the patrilineal lineage of its monarchs, from Ordoño II to Alfonso V
The image in this section shows the territory of the Inca Empire (Tawantinsuyu) overlaid on present-day South America, illustrating its extent before the arrival of colonizers in

Incas (Tawantinsuyu)

The study of the Inca Empire (Tawantinsuyu) like other scientific fields, is constantly evolving. Chronicles and research related to the empire indicate a general consensus about the lineage of Viracocha's descendants; however, it’s possible that some kings (Sapa) remain undocumented. Additionally, recent research challenges the traditional view of rapid territorial expansion, suggesting that this conclusion may be inaccurate
The Inca Empire (Tawantinsuyu) in the South American subcontinent (Abya Yala) is detailed in the genealogy of Inca kings (Sapa)

?
Reflection: External Influences (Part II)

In analyzing the account given by Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala on Inca rulers, we find an intriguing fragment where he describes Jesus Christ as the son of Mama Coca, wife (Coya) of Sinchi Roca. Interestingly, in another part of the same book, Guaman Poma presents Jesus Christ in a slightly different way, yet still anachronistically places him in the era of the Inca kings (Sapa) (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, pp. 87, 123 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, pp. 62, 89 ; Gebran, Philomena, pp. 6 - 7 ; History Tracers).

Imagine that you had never encountered any other version beyond Guaman Poma’s account; would you consider it an unquestionable truth?

In your opinion, can relying solely on specific sources limit access to other documents and hinder a broader understanding of different worldviews?

Minas Gerais - Brazil

The image in this section shows the current territory of Minas Gerais, in Brazil (Pindorama). The state has had this shape since approximately the end of the colonial period. The word "Pindorama", meaning "Land of the Palm Trees", was the name used to refer to the region before the arrival of colonizers

### Mesoamerica: The Beginning

Maps like those presented in the section *Continent: Africa* reflect historical divisions that have shaped the borders we recognize today. However, not all maps created by humans are intended to define borders. An example is the map in this section, which highlights a region known as Mesoamerica. This concept was not created by the Indigenous peoples of the region but was defined centuries later by anthropologist Paul Kirchhoff. He used this term to group cultures that shared common characteristics within a specific geographical area

### Mesoamerica: Different Frontiers

In the following pages of her work, Winifred Creamer analyzes other studies that, by considering additional factors such as technological systems, redefine and expand the original boundaries of Mesoamerica proposed by Paul Kirchhoff. The map presented in this section illustrates the broader region as described in some of the research reviewed by Creamer
